doc.title: Brazil Retail: With MELI exploring drugstore vertical, we review current regulation
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Brazil Retail_ With MELI exploring drugstore vertical, we review current regulation_2025-09-01

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: In light of the Aug 29 news of MELI's potential acquisition of a drugstore in Sao Paulo (link), we review the framework regulating the sale of medical drugs in Brazil. At first sight, we understand that even though the current regulatory framework (link) allows for orders to be placed remotely (i.e. online), these orders must be fulfilled by a licensed brick- and- mortar drugstore where the inventory is held. As a result, the scaling of a 1P online operation would require a relatively extensive network of brick- and- mortar locations to provide the operation with sufficiently broad reach and reasonable unit economics. While we appreciate that MELI's potential acquisition of this unit may serve as an initial pilot test to explore a vertical in which it currently under- indexes, we note the company has historically favored a relatively capital- light and platform- centred approach.

- The online sale of medicines must be conducted exclusively through the authorized drugstores' own website.- The location where the inventory is held must be a drugstore that is open to the public.- Each individual drugstore is a separately licensed entity with a responsible on-site pharmacist.

- The aggregator model of delivery platforms such as ifood or Rappi is one of the exceptions to the rule of drug sales coming strictly from a drugstore's own website. The regulation states that orders for medical drugs that are not subject to special controls can be placed remotely, via means such as phone or online; the regulation does not provide an extensive list of means by which an order can be placed, but also does not explicitly prohibit clients ordering through platforms that will execute the sale and delivery on the client's behalf.- However, we note that such sales, where the client places the order on the aggregator's website, which then intermediates the purchase, collection and delivery of the drug on behalf of the client, do involve an actual physical drugstore at which the order is purchased and fulfilled.- Based on the current regulation, our understanding is that MELI could look to
- Based on the current regulation, our understanding is that MELI could look to

Analysts employed by non- US affiliates are not registered/qualified as research analysts with FINRA in the U.S.

replicate the aggregator model and/or leverage the acquired drugstore for 1P direct- to- consumer sales, both on- and offline. However, we believe the latter would have a limited geographic reach in terms of the unit economics of delivery, catchment of foot traffic and inventory available for fulfillment. We note that:

It would most likely constitute a pilot operation for MELI to test a new vertical, rather than the basis for a rapidly scaling operation. The news comes at a time when MELI has looked to push deeper into new verticals, including those that drive greater purchase frequency with existing users and/or drive new users to the platform. Moreover, delivery platforms such as ifood (owned by Prosus, not covered), Didi and Meituan (covered by Ronald Keung) are increasing their level of investment in Brazil, with a focus to go beyond meal delivery into the quick commerce space. While MELI currently does not operate in this space in Brazil, the company has had a small restaurant delivery operation in Argentina for several years.

Finally, we note that regulation for the sale of medical drugs may continue to evolve, as illustrated by the push from food retail associations to be allowed to sell drugs (OTC or a broader selection) on their premises (see here).
RADL shifting sales of GLP- 1 drugs to its own online channel

RADL is reducing the inventory of GLP- 1 products across its overall network due to security concerns and increased shrinkage in this high- ticket product category. It is focusing the sale of these products in its own online channel, with the orders then being fulfilled from stores that operate in safer locations, i.e. inside shopping malls rather than on the high street. Orders are, however, still fulfilled by a specific store rather than its DC.
We are Buy rated on MELI shares. Our 12- month target price is \(\) 3,060\(. Our valuation methodology continues to be based on a multiple valuation (12m forward target P/E of 43X).

Key downside risks include: (i) FX volatility negatively impacting the translation of results, especially in the event of a potential devaluation of the Argentine Peso; (ii) weaker- than- expected operating margins due to upfront provisioning for new credit card loans, temporary operating deleverage from investments in logistics and due to potential negative mix effects; (iii) greater competition in the payment space, resulting in higher customer acquisition costs and potentially lower growth and returns; and (iv) increased competition from incumbent and new competitors in the core marketplace business.

We are Buy rated on RADL shares. Our 12- month target price is \(\) 21\(. Our valuation methodology is based on an equal- weighted blend of a FCFD DCF (WACC of 12.9\%) and forward P/E multiple of 21X.
Key downside risks include: (i) slower SSS growth; (ii) renewed pricing and mix
pressures; (iii) increased competition; (iv) execution of organic growth plan; (v) slower maturation of new stores/cannibalization; (vi) inflationary expense pressure.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.
